block.p: To the Editor: Suzanne Winckler's ''What's Doing in Phoenix'' (Nov. 28) certainly points out a number of the city's most interesting sights.

However, I was upset that in lauding Phoenix's canals, fountains and so on, she omitted that this water is draining off the formerly wild, beautiful rivers of the Southwest. Phoenix is living in water luxury that the environment cannot afford in the long term. Any visitor comparing Phoenix with southern Tucson will immediately note that while Phoenix is lush and green, Tucson is typified by desert landscaping because residents are forced to conserve water rather than waste it on things like shopping-center water sculptures.
To the Editor: Suzanne Winckler's ''What's Doing in Phoenix'' (Nov. 28) certainly points out a number of the city's most interesting sights.

However, I was upset that in lauding Phoenix's canals, fountains and so on, she omitted that this water is draining off the formerly wild, beautiful rivers of the Southwest. Phoenix is living in water luxury that the environment cannot afford in the long term. Any visitor comparing Phoenix with southern Tucson will immediately note that while Phoenix is lush and green, Tucson is typified by desert landscaping because residents are forced to conserve water rather than waste it on things like shopping-center water sculptures.
Is the point of living in Arizona to recreate, say, New England in spring, or is it to appreciate the desert's beauty?
